results.title: acousma
results.brief_description: It uses as its basis recordings of the electrical activity occuring within my brain during unconsciousness, to create a unique sound composition, a kind of audio representation of my dreams during sleep. This we realised through the use of software to systematically create audio transcriptions of both my EEG (electroencephalography) wave-traces and MRI images into sound, subsequently giving my unconscious mind a voice. The visual element of the piece consists of the entire sequence of MRI scans which were used in creating the soundtrack. These I animated in order that the viewer be taken on a highly unorthodox journey through the human head, as part of the experience

results.title: Sunrise at midnight
results.brief_description: Sunrise at Midnight is both a documentary portrait of Yumi Umiumare, a contemporary Japanese/Australian butoh dancer, and a Japanese Ghost story set in the Australian Desert. The film is inspired by an historic photograph of a troupe of Japanese female performers who toured outback towns at the turn of the century, and the tale of one such performer, Noriko, who wandered into the desert and never came back. Filmmaker Sean O’Brien and butoh Dancer Yumi Umiumare make an expedition into the desert to experience and exorcise Noriko’s lost soul.

results.title: 20 years @ Metro
results.brief_description:
From U-Matic Video and offline editing to digital media production and training this video tracks the history of community access to program making in Sydney. It includes interviews and footage of filmmakers Tom Zubrycki, David Caesar and Vincent Sheehan, broadcasters Steven Wall and Chris Winter and Filmink editor Dov Kornits who talk about starting out in video at Metro. It features early clips of Andrew Denton and Nicole Kidman and award winning films by indigenous filmmakers and young people from Metro’s youth access unit Channel Free.
Metro Screen began as the Paddington Video Access Centre in 1974, it incorporated as Metro Television Ltd in 1981 and organised the community television trials and was a key organisational player in he establishment of community television services. It became Metro Screen Ltd in 1998 and moved into digital video and interactive multimedia production and became a Registered Training Organisation.
Metro’s archive collection of community and independent programs represents over 27 years of documentaries, dramas and experimental videos. Communities who have not been represented in mainstream media - Aboriginals, gays and lesbians, young people and women present their communities, their issues and themselves.
The programs are products of exhaustive, laborious and triumphant collaborations between various individuals and community groups working within the spirit of a truly democratic and representative media.
In 2001 to celebrate 20 years at Metro, Metro Screen produced this 25 minute documentary using footage from the archive collection.
The next 20 years at Metro will build on the strengths of the past and continue to provide access and innovation in independent screen production and training top a wider regional and Western Sydney market through mobile and online services.

results.title: Et cetera. Episode 3 [1999 Melbourne Fringe Festival]
results.creator_credit: David McLauchlan, Michael Costello and Northern Access TV
results.brief_description:
Documents the 1999 Melbourne Fringe Festival Parade and the Fringe Furniture Exhibition, including interviews with Virginia Hyam, Fringe Director, and Axel, Fringe Furniture Co-ordinator. The Melbourne Fringe Festival has become an institution since its inception in 1982 when a small group of independent artists gathered together to create a platform to present new and independent art to the community. From those early beginnings the Melbourne-based festival now attracts interstate and international guests and covers a wide variety of arts
performances including outdoor events such as the Annual Parade in Brunswick Street, Fitzroy, the Annual Waiter’s Race, street-theatre and live bands and indoor events including comedy and cabaret, music and theatre. The Fringe Furniture Exhibition allows for young students
and designers an opportunity to show-off their creative ability and caters for non-mainstream pieces. Crazy, outrageous, quirky and even occasionally practical, the Exhibition contains an amazing selection of eclectic pieces as witnessed in this documentary program.
Reporters: Melissa Iaria and Phillip Taylor.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David McLauchlan, Michael Costello and Northern Access TV

results.title: Viva Falantil!
results.creator_credit: Campbell Manderson, Pip Starr and SKA TV
results.brief_description: Report on a group of performers and activists who stowed away on a UN flight bound for East Timor to raise awareness of the plight of the Falintil people and their 20 year struggle against the East Timorese military. A tour through a newly-independent East Timor, still shell-shocked and facing an uncertain future. This story examines the possibilities for and obstacles to building a democratic nation. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: S.T.O.P. Surviving Time outside Prison
results.creator_credit: Campbell Manderson, Pip Starr and SKA TV
results.brief_description: Awareness-raising report on the plight of ex-prisoners of Deer Park correctional facility to secure adequate support for women who have been released from prison. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: Herald Sun Occupation
results.creator_credit: Campbell Manderson, Pip Starr and SKA TV
results.brief_description: During the World Economic Forum (WEF) held in Melbourne in September 2000, a group of protesters went to the Herald Sun newspaper to voice their concern the paper’s exceptionally biased coverage of the protests outside the WEF. Screened as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: Emu Spew
results.creator_credit: Campbell Manderson, Pip Starr and SKA TV
results.brief_description: Report on the efforts of the Adnyamathanha people, traditional landowners of the Northern Flinders Rangers to stop the Beverly Uranium Mining Project. The report also covers police action against the protestors and the unsafe method the mining company are using to extract the uranium. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: Fortress Goolengook
results.creator_credit: Campbell Manderson, Pip Starr and SKA TV
results.brief_description: After having their camp destroyed by loggers, forest blockaders in the heart of East Gippsland’s Goolengook forest build an elaborate fortress (including drawbridge!) to ensure their safety against further attacks. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.
